intro: Houstonia acerosa var. tamaulipana, commonly known as the Tamaulipan bluemink, is a flowering plant native to the southern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family, which includes over 13,000 species of flowering plants. The plant is characterized by its delicate blue to violet flowers and low-growing habit, often forming dense mats on the ground. It thrives in sandy or rocky soils and is typically found in open woodlands and grasslands. Due to its limited distribution, it is considered a rare and endangered species in some regions.
